hints_html: Recall that a unique solution implies there are no free variables; all pivots are 1.
hints_latex:
Recall that a unique solution implies there are no free variables; all
pivots are 1.
hints_raw: Recall that a unique solution implies there are no free variables; all pivots are 1.
question: B 06 (a)
sols_html:
For a vector x, with components \(x_1\) and \(x_2\), the unique solution is

\[\begin{aligned} x_1&=2,\\ x_2&=3.\end{aligned}\]

Since there is a unique solution all pivots must be 1. Since we have two equations in two unknowns we have 2 rows and 2 columns. Therefore the augmented matrix would look like

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 0 & 2\\ 0 & 1 & 3 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
For a vector '''x''', with components <math>x_1</math> and <math>x_2</math>, the unique solution is

:<math>
\begin{align}
x_1&=2,\\
x_2&=3.
\end{align}
</math>

Since there is a unique solution all pivots must be 1.  Since we have two equations in two unknowns we have 2 rows and 2 columns.  Therefore the augmented matrix would look like

:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{cc|c}
1  &  0  &  2\\
0  &  1  &  3
\end{array}\right]
</math>
statement_html:
Consider the linear systems described below. In cases (a)-(d), write a single, possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix of the system.

Two equations in two unknowns with unique solution

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 3 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Consider the linear systems described below.  In cases (a)-(d), write a ''single'', possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix of the system.

Two equations in two unknowns with unique solution

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3
\end{bmatrix}
</math>.
